snippet.title: Tributes for marine presumed dead in Queensland MV-22 Osprey crash
snippet.content:
Friends and family have named a Kansas man as one of three American marines missing, presumed dead, after an aircraft crash off the coast of Queensland. Tributes were being shared on Monday as Australian navy divers were deployed to the crash site at military training area Shoalwater Bay, near Rockhampton.Photo: Facebook Nathan Ordway's sister, Taylor, asked other supporters of the 31st Marine Expeditionary Unit to pray for her brother and the two other missing marines. Several other friends paid tribute to the young marine, reported to be a corporal.Photo: Facebook "I ask my friends to keep my friends the Ordways in your prayers please," family friend Heidi Peltzer posted. "Their son Nathan Ordway is one of the missing Marines from the Osprey Helicopter crash off the Australian coast Saturday & there is still no news about him.
"Please pray for his life, his safety, and comfort for the family."

Authorities have warned it could take months to recover the tilt-rotor aircraft MV-22 Osprey, after it crashed about 4pm on Saturday during a military exercise. The Osprey had launched from the USS Bonhomme Richard amphibious assault ship when the "mishap" occurred. The aircraft, carrying 26 people, reportedly hit the deck of the USS Green Bay and slid into the water. On Sunday, family members of the three missing marines received the news that the search for survivors had been called off, replaced with a recovery operation. "Prayers forfamily (sic) and friends of Nathan Ordway he was one of the ones on the v22 crash in Australia," Jon Dakota posted to Facebook. "I left mct with him. This is crazy." A 36-year-old man, one of the 23 marines who survived the crash, was flown from Rockhampton Hospital to Brisbane for further treatment to a broken leg. Australia has sent the navy survey ship HMAS Melville to the area, along with a navy clearance diving team. Defence Minister Marise Payne said the Australian government was supporting the US forces. "These recovery operations are complex in nature and are affected by a range of factors including weather conditions, water depth, debris and water current," she said, in a statement. It is the 10th known crash involving an Osprey - a tilt-rotor aircraft that takes off and lands like a helicopter but flies like an aeroplane - since 1991. US President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull were briefed on the incident, while Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk also offered her government's support. - With Toby Crockford and AAP
